title: 107_s22
content: The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for increased disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, and software for filing reports. It also addresses limits on soft money of national political party committees, contribution limits, and miscellaneous provisions such as prohibiting solicitation of political party soft money in Federal buildings and updating penalty amounts. SEC. 101. ADDITIONAL MONTHLY AND QUARTERLY DISCLOSURE REPORTS. SEC. 101 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 regarding monthly and quarterly reports for Principal Campaign Committees. Monthly reports are now required to be filed by the 20th day after the last day of the month, except for November and December. Quarterly reports must be filed by the 15th day after the last day of each calendar quarter. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require monthly reports to be filed by the 20th day after the last day of the month, except for November and December. Quarterly reports must be filed by the 15th day after the last day of each calendar quarter. Additionally, a national committee of a political party is required to file the reports as specified. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require monthly reports instead of quarterly reports. Section 309 is also amended to change "calendar quarter" to "month". SEC. 102 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to require national political party committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period. If a committee receives or spends over $200 from a person in a calendar year, it must itemize the reporting for that person. Reports must be filed for the same time periods as political committees under subsection (a). SEC. 103 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require the Commission to make reports available on the Internet within 24 hours of receiving the information. SEC. 104 provides public access to broadcasting records. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require licensees to maintain and make public a record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. This includes requests made by or on behalf of candidates for public office or messages on national legislative issues. The record must include information on whether the broadcast time request was accepted or rejected. Licensees must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters of national importance. The record includes details such as acceptance or rejection of the request, rate charged, date and time of airing, class of time purchased, candidate's name and office sought, and information on the requester. Licensees must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters of national importance, including details such as the requester's information, candidate's details, and time of airing. The information must be placed in a political file promptly and retained for at least 2 years. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require the development and use of software for filing reports. The Commission must provide the software at no cost to those required to file reports. Additionally, there are limits on soft money of national political party committees. SEC. 324 of Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 imposes limits on soft money contributions of national political party committees. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Limitation on donations, gifts, or transfers of funds to political party committees. Aggregate limit on donors set at $60,000 per calendar year, with adjustments based on price index. Expedited Review and Appeal Process: Any individual or entity affected by a section of the Federal Election Campaign Act may challenge its constitutionality in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. The court's decision can be directly appealed to the Supreme Court within specific timeframes. Both courts are required to prioritize and expedite these cases. The District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court of the United States must prioritize and expedite the resolution of any challenges to the constitutionality of provisions in the Federal Election Campaign Act. Enforcement of the challenged provision is suspended from the filing of the action until the Supreme Court's final decision. This process applies to actions filed within 30 days of the Act's effective date. SEC. 203. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. Increase in contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, including raising individual and political committee limits to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000 respectively. Multicandidate limits also increased to $7,500 with exceptions noted. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. The limits are raised to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000 respectively, with multicandidate limits set at $7,500, except for national committees exceeding $15,000. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. Limits are raised annually by a certain percentage, with specific provisions for limitations under subsections (a) and (h) to remain in effect for a 2-year period. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for individuals and political committees. The amendments include raising the limits for Senate candidate contributions for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees. The effective dates for these amendments are specified for calendar years after December 31, 2001, and after December 31, 2002 for certain provisions. SEC. 301 of Title III prohibits the solicitation of political party soft money in federal buildings. It amends Section 607 of Title 18, United States Code, to define "contribution" and include a prohibition of donations. SEC. 302 updates penalty amounts under the Federal Election Campaign Act based on inflation. SEC. 303 requires Senate reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. SEC. 303 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require all filings to be submitted to the Commission. Conforming amendments are made to ensure consistency in filing requirements.
